How to write "hookable" software?
description:
Does anybody have any resources/references/design patterns/guides/blog posts/etc for building software that is designed to be extensible by users? I have a Kubernetes controller that I’d like to build in some user extension points for, and I’m not really sure the best way to go about this.

My rough requirements are

  1. Users should be able to write in whatever language they want (or, at the very least, they shouldn’t have to recompile the controller binary)
  2. I guess I’d prefer to avoid having a network call/grpc schema/whatever, but maybe that’s the most practical way to do this?
  3. I’d like a system that can potentially accommodate adding additional extension points in the future

Security (for now) is a non-requirement, the people writing and running this code will already have cluster-admin access to the cluster, and there won’t be a way to accept untrusted code without the person with cluster-admin access approving it.
description_plain:
Does anybody have any resources/references/design patterns/guides/blog posts/etc for building software that is designed to be extensible by users?  I have a Kubernetes controller that I'd like to build in some user extension points for, and I'm not really sure the best way to go about this.

My rough requirements are

1. Users should be able to write in whatever language they want (or, at the _very_ least, they shouldn't have to recompile the controller binary)
2. I guess I'd _prefer_ to avoid having a network call/grpc schema/whatever, but maybe that's the most practical way to do this?
3. I'd like a system that can potentially accommodate adding additional extension points in the future

Security (for now) is a non-requirement, the people writing and running this code will already have cluster-admin access to the cluster, and there won't be a way to accept untrusted code without the person with cluster-admin access approving it.

why is there so little of anything online about old phone UIs, firmwares and emulation?
description:
i had some pre-android phones, the ones that could run jar files and stuff. i really liked the gui systems on them. but i can’t find much about them online

there’s websites about old desktop UIs (http://toastytech.com/guis/), modern recreations of their visuals (https://github.com/themesberg/windows-95-ui-kit), old pc emulators (https://infinitemac.org/), parodies (https://www.windows93.net/), even some PDA emulators (https://wuffs.org/WindEmu/index.html), but nothing like that about phones? there are some emulators (https://github.com/nikita36078/J2ME-Loader), but afaik they are all just for running game executables and don’t emulate the full user-facing phone OS.

but it’s not like those mobile phones were than uncommon, it’s weird that i can’t find almost anything documenting or reviewing those UIs and OSes, i hope i’m just not googling it right. do you know of any resources about them?
description_plain:
i had some pre-android phones, the ones that could run jar files and stuff. i really liked the gui systems on them. but i can't find much about them online

there's websites about old desktop UIs (http://toastytech.com/guis/), modern recreations of their visuals (https://github.com/themesberg/windows-95-ui-kit), old pc emulators (https://infinitemac.org/), parodies (https://www.windows93.net/), even some PDA emulators (https://wuffs.org/WindEmu/index.html), but nothing like that about phones? there are some emulators (https://github.com/nikita36078/J2ME-Loader), but afaik they are all just for running game executables and don't emulate the full user-facing phone OS.

but it's not like those mobile phones were than uncommon, it's weird that i can't find almost anything documenting or reviewing those UIs and OSes, i hope i'm just not googling it right. do you know of any resources about them?
